Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EARS: Cognitive and Efficient Spectrum Access in Autonomous Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to enable more efficient and reliable operation of autonomous femtocell networks with agile spectrum access, autonomous interference control, as well as intelligent network self-organization and self-optimization. This project falls into four interacted thrusts: 1) Incorporate cognition into the femtocell networks to cognitively reuse the available spectrum sensed; 2) Develop distributed, dynamic and cooperative interference management schemes exploiting antenna techniques and based on sensed environmental conditions; 3) Investigate the scenarios and schemes that femtocells can be exploited to facilitate macrocell transmissions, and the potential gains in capacity, coverage and reliability; 4) Incorporate interference cancellation for data multicast, and develop techniques to support multiuser video streaming. The project also develops a testbed with open source programmable wireless platforms, for prototyping and evaluating the effectiveness of various techniques developed.

The proposed research has the potential to significantly increase the capacity and resilience of existing and future wireless networks. The agility and resilience of the system will also make it instrumental to support communications and applications that are important for national security and economy. The PIs will facilitate technology transfer through their industrial partners and industry affiliate programs. Complementary to the research agenda, the project will carry out a broad range of education and outreach activities, including integration of research findings into the courses, promoting underrepresented and undergraduate populations, and engaging with the K-12 schools to raise the level of student interests in pursuing advanced education and career in the areas of engineering and mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The exponential growth of wireless traffic calls for novel and efficient spectrum access techniques and wireless network infrastructures. The introduction of the autonomous network concept, where femtocell is a key component, presents a paradigm shift from traditional cellular networks with planned deployment and centralized management to more autonomous, uncoordinated, and intelligent rollouts of small base stations deployed by end users and overlaying wide area cellular networks. The combination of wide-area coverage to meet the basic and mobile user requirements and the organic growth of small cells for hot-spot coverage and improving per-area spectral efficiency appears to be the most promising technique that can lead to multi-fold capacity increase needed for future wireless networks. Fundamentally different from conventional cellular networks or heterogeneous networks with nodes operating in different spectrum bands, femtocells are deployed in an ad hoc manner and share the same spectrum band as the cellular networks to increase the spectrum usage efficiency and allow a terminal to seamlessly operate in macrocells and femtocells. This network infrastructure, however, would create strong cross-tier and intra-tier interference.

This project has been focused on how to enable efficient and reliable operation of autonomous femtocell networks for significantly higher spectral efficiency and network capacity with agile spectrum access, autonomous interference control, as well as self-organization and self-optimization of the network. During the project years, research has been conducted to address the following problems. Frist, research has been done on incorporating cognition into femtocell networks to cognitively reuse the available spectrum. Algorithms have been developed for radio environment awareness and spectrum sharing, exploring various learning and adaptation techniques. Second, various dynamic and cooperative interference management schemes have been studied to increase the throughput and reliability of autonomous wireless networks, by exploiting antenna techniques and based on sensed environmental conditions. Third, scenarios and schemes have been investigated where femtocells can be exploited to facilitate macrocell transmissions, and studied the potential gains that can be achieved in capacity, coverage and reliability. Fourth, this research also addressed how to incorporate successive interference cancellation for data multicast, and interesting problems in multiuser video streaming, such as theoretical models for the capacity of autonomous femtocell networks in carrying realtime data, qualify of experience (QoE) provisioning, and supporting realtime interactive videos.

In addition to the above theoretical studies, simulation software and software defined radio experiments have been developed and conducted for validation the performance of the proposed algorithms and schemes. Both theoretical and experimental work has been carried out collaboratively between academic and industrial researchers and involved the interplay of techniques across disciplines such as computer and information science, engineering, technology and applications.

The outcome from this project achieved great advances in area of autonomous wireless networks, and made contributions to the advance toward the future 5G wireless networks. The developed theory and algorithms can effectively enhance wireless network capacity and resilience, which can enable new services and applications and reduce the communication cost. The investigators have also worked closely with the industrial partners to disseminate the outcomes and enable rapid technology transfer. The findings have been incorporated into the graduate courses offered at Stony Brook University and Auburn University. Many graduate students have been involved in this project, working on various research projects as part of their thesis work, while a few undergraduate students have been supported by the NSF research experience for undergrads (REU) program to work on this project, including several students from underrepresented groups. The research outcomes have been widely disseminated in the conferences and journals in the wireless field as well as the project website.
